author: redbeardlegoman
title: Absolute BT1TUDE
review:
Summary

I've got several Batmobiles, and I love them all, but while they tend towards the sleek, this brawny black bruiser is the baddest one since the Tumbler.

Box/Instructions

I rarely have much to say about the boxes, and this review will be no exception.

The instructions come in two parts, with the second, thinner book basically dedicated to the wheel assemblies.

Each of the numbered bags contain one of the five minifigures to build as you go along.  I have to say I like that.  I'm a huge fan of minifigures, especially when it comes to the DC and Marvel Superhero lines (having bought a few sets just to get them).  Having one in each of the bags is like a small treat as you progress.  It became something to look forward to, and I think it would be a pleasant idea for TLG to continue.  I know it's happened more-or-less in other sets, but I don't remember it happening before in any large set that I've bought.

Parts

There are a few parts in here that I really like.  The stubby wings at the back, for instance are nice.  I think if the older-style, huge dragon wings had been used, as they often are, it would have not worked as well as these ones do.  And of course, new moulds almost always open up new opportunities for building.

I love the black gold ingots.  They add an interesting touch of texture to the build, and will have lots of future MOC applications.  I hope this means that other colours are coming/available.

The printed black 1x1 round brick and yellow 1x1 round tiles are great.  I love the yellow tile especially.  I want to put little bat symbols on everything.

Minifigures

As I said, I love minifigures - especially the Superheroes.  This is my first standard TLBM Batman (though I know I'm fated to have many, many more).  I absolutely love the utility belt piece.  It add a little je ne sais quoi.  That's not to say that it's superior to a painted on belt, but I do like the variety.  Plus, I can see it coming out in other colours in the future to be a cool accessory for non-Batman themes.

Usually the worst thing about Batman is Robin.  I loathe Robin in pretty much any non-Nightwing incarnation.  Having said that, however, this Robin looks good.  The dual-moulded sleeves and legs, the bright colours, the disturbing underpant thong, the shiny yellow cape all come together in an aesthetically pleasing, brightly coloured, surprisingly lovely minifigure.  I'm even coming to terms with his stupid green goggles on his stupid Robin face - that's just how good this minifigure looks.

But he's not allowed to hold that adorable Bat-merch Gun.  He is Robin, after all.

One of the things that I like about the CMF run for The LEGO Batman Movie, and most recent wave of DC sets is the inclusion of lesser-known characters.  The Kabuki Twins are two that I'm not particularly familiar with, but it's nice to have a couple more characters to add to my Rouges Gallery.  It's not likely that they'll ever be released in another set, so this is the only real chance to satisfy the completist monkey on my back.

I'm of two minds over Man-Bat, though I think I favour the second mind.  I already have Man-Bat from 76011, and this one is exactly the same.  Plus, I don't really see what Man-Bat has to do with a ground-based set.  In 76011 he was pitted against the Batcopter, more appropriately. But that's the perspective of a 40-year-old pedant with a discretionary income.

That Man-Bat was originally released three years ago, in a long-since-retired set.  If kids today, or people just emerging from their Dark Ages, want one, and don't want to have to hunt through the secondary market (and who-knows-what-prices), then this is a good opportunity.  I favour this situation.  I've got a young daughter who loves both LEGO and comics.  I have no problem with obscure figures being re-released in sets down the road.

It also brings up a minor excursion into value.  This set is already $75 dollars retail in Canada.  That's not peanuts.  So, if re-using a Man-Bat adds a minifigure (fittingly or not) for the kids (and some adults), helps keep the price slightly reigned-in, and even slightly reduces the prices for said minifigure on the secondary market, then I'm onboard 100%.

The Build

I could say lots and lots and lots about the build, but simply put it was one of the best builds I've ever done.  It was a lot of fun.  There were a few techniques I thought were interesting.  I also liked some of the parts usage.  For instance, the grey air scoop near the windscreen is brick-build, simply and elegantly, using 2 or 3 parts.  It would have been so easy to just add the air scoop brick.  But this one also works with the lines of the vehical and is, I feel, clever.

The build is pretty stable throughout the whole process, which is good, because you have to rotate it a lot while building (or at least, I did).  That stability stays through to the completed model.  Speaking of which...

... The Completed Model

This thing looks awesome!  It really does.

Say what you will about stickers, those licence plates and Bat Symbol hub caps are pretty.  I'm generally not one to engage in the sticker/printed piece debate.

Likewise, I love the dragon-spine grill at the front.  I keep wondering if it would look better in black (or very, very dark grey), but it works for me.  It also leads the eye to the excellently placed Batarang hood ornament.  It's a little bit Batman attitude and Bruce Wayne Rolls Royce extravagance that is sublime and delightful.

And while the joke may be that the Batman works only in black, and sometimes very, very dark grey, all the while never doing that exactly, I want to say that the inclusion of red here and there was inspired.  The red pin-striping, both brick-build and sticker-added works to make this Batmobile a real 70's muscle car style beauty.

The greebly look of the undercarriage and wheel assemblies is satisfying in a Top Gear petrol-head way.  And the six pipes coming out of the enormous engine housing look great.

It's got the near-ubiquitous stud shooters, but they are discretely hidden by the stubby wings, and don't stand out distractingly on the model like a thoughtless Marketing Department tumor.

This is going to look great on my shelf, for years to come, and even better in the I-really-will-build-it-one-day-honest Bat Cave MOC I'm planning.

Overall Opinion

Perhaps it's my Scottish blood that makes me balk at $75 dollars for a set.

And though I was lucky enough to find it on Kijiji for $30, I have to say that it would have been totally worth the retail price.  It's big, it's awesome, it's solid, it's surprisingly heavy.  Five minifigures, one of whom is a Robin that almost makes me not hate Robin, make for immediate play value.

Just as Dick Grayson wandered through the Bat Cave, growing more excitable with each Bat-vehicle discovery, so to has my progression, through various LEGO incarnations of the Batmobile, led me to this baaaad mutha of pure delight.  She's not like her slinky sisters.  This lady is all beautiful BT1TUDE.
